title: Future IT Major
body: I really want to go to college and major in IT and want to work with video games. It would be nice to eventually work for Riot and help them with this great game they have created. But, i am not sure what exactly i want to do in this field, any ideas or tips? Thanks!{{champion:80}}

replies.body:
Hey TI Spartan! 

I've been doing stuff in this general area for a while now and I'm just now getting around to getting my certifications. The first thing you should decide on is if you want to deal with hardware or software more, as the paths to these careers differ greatly. If you want to deal with hardware and repairs, you can get your certifications (CompTIA, Cisco, etc.) and you should be fine. If you want to be a software developer, you should go for a computer science degree.

There are a lot of really cool jobs you can have in this field. A lot of people tend to assume that "oh you're a computer guy" and lump everyone together in the same pool. Really, you could be a network engineer, work in information security, or even one of my favorites, a network penetrator. Those guys use all the tools they have to hack into networks and show companies where their faults in security lie, then come up with solutions for them and implement it.

There's really a lot you can do in this field and it's great to see that you already know you want to work with computers. I would suggest checking out YouTube for some help on deciding what you want to do. Look up DefCon videos and watch some of the presentations there. [Here's one of my favorites](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U4oB28ksiIo). It's only about 20 minutes long, and a lot of the videos average 45-60 minutes, but it's definitely worth the watch!
Thanks a lot! I will definitely look into the hardware and software to make my decision, you helped me alot! :D
Awesome! Let me know if you need help with anything else!
Elduris, Is there anything i should do or learn before going to college to go after a computer science degree?

I'm not an expert, but that's a pretty basic place to start, so you should learn a lot of the fundamentals in your classes. If you want a head start, familiarize yourself with the parts that make up the computer, learn how to put one together and take one apart.
**Elduris**, oh how I've missed you on the boards. I guess things are pretty busy, huh.
Haha, yeah you could say that. ^_^

I went for an internet security degree.

Got to do a little of everything, A+ stuff, cisco classes, programming, etc. Gave me a better idea of what everyone does, and had I a mind to change to a different major, I could have. (I almost jumped over to straight programming, that is fun.) 

I stuck with a focus on routing (also fun) and continued a Cisco education after college.


Id say start with something that had a bit of everything as requirements, make a decision once you know which discipline you enjoy.
Okay i will, thank you. I will make sure to look into all the different careers and choose one to focus on.
